attributes.title: Public policy options to control smokeless tobacco consumption at national level: what, how and for whom - A scoping review

q1.value: Public policy options to control smokeless tobacco consumption at national level: what, how and for whom - A scoping review

q2.value: Sarah Forberger, Khan, Zohaib, Ahmad, Fayaz, Ullah, Safat, Ahmad Furqan, Omara Dogar, Kamran Siddiqi, Hajo Zeeb

q3.value:
Background
Smokeless tobacco is consumed by 356 million people globally [1]. It is a leading cause of head and neck cancers. Worldwide, the geographical distribution of smokeless tobacco consumption varies considerably. Most smokeless tobacco users (82%) live in Southeast Asia, Central Asia and in many African states (e.g. Nigeria, Ghana, Algeria, Cameroon, Chad, Senegal, Sudan and South Africa) [2]. Most lethal and addictive products are used in Asia and Africa. Depending on the production of the product and its use, the level of health risk to users varies widely [3]. Smokeless tobacco use is strongly associated with oral potentially malignant disorders, head and neck cancers and cardiovascular deaths. Its use during pregnancy is also associated with low birth weight, preterm births, stillbirths and small-for-gestation-age babies. However, smokeless tobacco use is often rooted in cultural traditions and use patterns are determined by wealth and educational inequalities [1]. Other factors that contribute towards high demand for smokeless tobacco use include easy availability at cheap prices, unregulated marketing (including over the internet) and advertising in print media and at point‐of‐sale. In addition, levels of awareness about the harmful effects of smokeless tobacco are low, compared with smoking. 
Global efforts to control smokeless tobacco use trail behind the progress made in the regulation of cigarette consumption. Smokeless tobacco products fall under the policy framework of the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention for Tobacco Control (FCTC). Their demand patterns, diverse nature, distinct health risks and supply chain require a special policy and practice approach. 
While the WHO FCTC provides a framework to analyze public tobacco control policies, smokeless tobacco is always in the background. In its review, Mehrotra et al. (2019) reviewed the state of implementation of the WHO FCTC in 180 countries worldwide [4]. This scoping review will add to this work by analyzing whether there are other policy options discussed in the scientific literature and how the options are assessed by the authors of the articles (reasons for or against the analyzed option).
	

Objectives
Research question
The aim is to map policy options to control smokeless tobacco use that are subject of scientific research and to compare these options with the WHO FCTC articles and the work of Mehrotra et al. (2019). The result will provide us with information about the areas in which policies exist, but also show gaps that may offer alternative approaches.
The overarching research question is: Are there policy options reported in the scientific research literature to control smokeless tobacco consumption at the national level that are not mentioned in the WHO-FCTC articles and that may enrich the options available?

Aims of the scoping review are:
1)	 To map public smokeless tobacco control policy; areas covered, instruments used (information (media, interpersonal), economic means (incentives, disincentives, in kind), regulations (soft/hard law, conditional, unconditional) and target group addressed to tackle smokeless tobacco use 
2)	To map the instruments used 
3)	To collect arguments for or against the used option
4)	To compare the approaches identified with WHO FCTC articles and existing public policy control mechanisms in place within countries [4]
The research reflects the so-called PICO elements being an acronym for population, intervention, comparator and outcome. 
The study population covers the whole population as we are analysing public policies targeting countries population. Specific populations might be considered as long as they are part of a policy issued by a state/public body.
The interventions in focus are public policies that mean policies issued by state bodies/public actors targeting the reduction of smokeless tobacco use within a country’s population (e.g., national, federal, regional or municipal public bodies).
Study results are compared either against the policy objective or against results in other countries. The results mentioned in the studies are used as a benchmark. Due to the diversity of policy approaches and the different country settings, no predefined results are used that go beyond effectiveness or ineffectiveness. However, all other results mentioned are collected for critical evaluation.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The scoping review will be based on the Joanna Briggs Institute methodology for Scoping Reviews [5] using the preferred reporting items for systematic reviews [6] and the transparent reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analyses “PRISMA” flowchart. Although scoping reviews follow a similar approach to systematic reviews [7, 8], they differ in terms of objectives and key characteristics. They answer broader questions that go beyond those related to the effectiveness of treatments or interventions and aim to (a) map existing literature in terms of nature, features and volume, (b) clarify work definitions and conceptual boundaries and (c) identify gaps in the existing literature and research [9, 10]. The scoping review will include a critical appraise to show the level of available evidence regarding the research question.

question.value:
Search Strategy
Search String
A search string will be developed by the author team with the help of our research librarian. The search will be developed in an iterative process [11]. The search string will be tested and refined by examining the research results. The agreed research string will be applied in all databases with the necessary adaption of the syntax to the databases.

Languages
Searches will be performed without language restrictions. 

Databases
Search will be performed in the following bibliographic databases: Medline, PsycInfo,	Science Citation Index Expanded, CINHAL, Econ.Lit, ASSIA, IBSS.

Supplementary Search
The identified and included reviews will be screened for additional references.

Article Screening and Study Inclusion Criteria
Screening Strategy
Retrieved publications will be organized with the reference management software EndNote and later managed with Covidence. On the first step, duplicates will be removed in EndNote, first within each database and then across databases. A second duplication check will be performed in Covidence. After duplication removal, Covidence will be used for the screening. The screening procedure is based on predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria (Table 3 attachment). Within the screening process, first all titles and abstract will be screened to determine if they match with the predefined inclusion criteria. In the following stage, included papers will be screened against the inclusion/exclusion criteria to be included in the scoping review. All screening will be done at least by two reviewers independently. In case of articles dealing with the same study, the articles will be linked and analyzed as one unit for eligibility so that all data is available to be considered when making eligibility decisions [12].
Any disagreements will be either resolved by consensus or by discussion with a third reviewer. If no decision can be reached, studies in doubt will be discussed with an expert who is not involved in the screening process. 
If any doubt about eligibility exists, studies will be included in the next step. If after the screening process the eligibility of the studies remains unclear, further information will be sought, also by contacting the study authors [12]. If uncertainty persists, the study will be excluded. 


Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
Articles had to be excluded if pdf is not available after contacting the authors or via research gate or through inter-library loans. The article will be marked as no full text available.  Overview of the inclusion/exclusion criteria (Table 3 attachment). 

Study type
All study designs (experimental and observational) are included in the scoping review. Studies must focus on public policy regulations to reduce smokeless tobacco use. 

Critical Appraisal
To provide policy option, the study results will be summarized narrative, assessing the outcome and evidence-base. Further a critical appraisal will be performed based on the checklists of the Center for Evidence Based Management, depending on the study design under question (systematic review, controlled study, panel study, cohort study, cross-sectional study, survey, qualitative study, case study). The questions will follow general approaches, and will be specified in accordance of the study design:
-	Did the study address a clearly focused question / issue?
-	Is the research method (study design) appropriate for answering the research question?
-	Are the results credible, and if so, are they relevant for practice?
-	Are the conclusions drawn justified by the results?
-	Are the findings of the study transferable to other settings?

Category	 & Characteristics
1	Author:	All authors of the publication
2	Year:	Year of publication
3	Title:	
4	Journal/Volume/Page number	
5	Origin:	Country of origin
6	Aim:	Aim of the public police
7	Timeframe:	Since when is the policy in place
8	Description:	Short description and objectives of the public policy
9	Intervention:	If the policy is operationalized and specific interventions are mentioned, specify for each intervention mentioned:
(a) Specific Intervention 
(b) Objectives of the specific intervention
(c) Target group of the specific intervention
(d) Setting of the specific intervention
(e) Instruments used
(f) Results of the specific intervention if specified in the paper
10	Results:	Results of overall intervention
11	Policy Options:	Policy option recommended for public policy control with reasoning for or against specific options

Results will be synthesized in accordance to the extraction sheet. A narrative synthesis will be used to describe the body of evidence. Various forms of visualizations, such as tables and charts will be used to group the results. Boundaries for the visualization will depend on the actual extracted evidence. Further, results will be compared to WHO FCTC articles and against the results of Mehrotra et al. 2019 review (overview about public policy control mechanism currently in place in 186 countries) [4] to reveal gaps or approaches not used so far.

attributes.title: Failure, self-awareness avoidance, and cognitive effort
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
Memory recall (failure vs disappointment): between-participant

Situational judgment problem (self-focusing vs others-focused): within participant
These variables are orthogonal.

question2b.value:
Two different measures refer to self-awareness avoidance (DV):
Number of chosen self-focusing judgment problems
Number of chosen others-focused judgment problems

question10b.value:
Participants

XXX undergraduate students at the University of Poitiers received partial course credit for participation in what was presented as a memory and judgment study. Participants were randomly assigned to one of the two boxes of a plan 2 (memory recall: failure, disappointment) x 2 (situational judgment problem: self vs other). The first variable is between-subject and the second is within-subject.

Materials, procedure and measures

Memory recall and performance at situational judgment problem
The experience included two tasks. The first task was a recall of memory (failure or disappointment). In the experimental condition, participants had to recall a failure in an area important to them where they had a lower performance compared to another person. They also had to detail the traits that characterized them, and which may have contributed to their failure. In the control condition, participants were asked to recall a disappointment where someone close to them had behaved below their expectations. They also had to detail the traits that characterized the person and that may have contributed to the disappointing behavior.
The second task was a computer-based situational problem judgment task and was designed with PsychoPy.

After reading the information form and completing the consent forms, participants received a document. This document contained three sheets:
•	A sheet with questions about socio-demographic data
•	A sheet with the instruction of the first task and below a box to write the memory
•	A sheet with the presentation of the second task and an example of a situational judgment problem.
On the first task, participants had fifteen minutes to write a memory. After completing the first task, participants had to open the door for the experimenter to explain the second task. Then participants had to read the third sheet and they had to click "OK" to start the computer-based task. The explanations and instructions were written on the screen.
On the first task, participants had fifteen minutes to write a memory. After completing the first task, participants had to open the door for the experimenter to explain the second task. Then participants had to read the third sheet and they had to click "OK" to start the computer-based task. The explanations and instructions were written on the screen.
The second task was presented as part of data collection for standardizing the test. Participants were asked to choose between two types of situational judgment problems: type 1 (by pressing the “1” key) and type 2 (by pressing the “2” key). Problems type 1 and 2 did not differentiate between them and served to distract participants from identifying the protagonist either by "you" or by a first name in the situational judgment problem statement.
After choosing the type of problem, they read a problem of situational judgment. The protagonist was identified either with the term "you" or with a first name. Then participants could choose to either respond to the problem (by pressing the “A” key), decline the problem and move on to the next (by pressing the “P” key), or terminate the experiment (by pressing the “G” key ). For each situational judgment problem, they were asked to indicate the most effective behavior and then the least effective behavior. To address situational judgment problem, for each of the two responses (most efficient and least efficient behavior) they had to choose among four statements and press the key “1”, “2”, “3” or “4”. Participants could terminate the computer-based task whenever they wanted.

question4b.value: Participants must be 18 years old or older.

question5b.value: Data from participants will be collected in part via paper and pencil questionnaire for the socio-demographic data and the recall of memory, and in part using PsychoPy software for the computer-based task.

question6b.value: We used effect size and correlation between repeated measures from a comparable prior study. We had access to approximately 100 participants, which gave us than .99 power to detect an effect of the same size as in the previous study, if there is one in the population.

question7b.value: Data collection will end when the required number of participants (100) is reached.

question8b.value:
Data will be screened for outliers based on a 2.5MAD criterion (Leys et al., 2013).

Participants will be excluded if they did not recall a memory (personal failure or disappointment) during the first task.

question1a.value:
Memory recall effect: self-awareness should be more unpleasant when recalling failure rather than disappointment

Situational judgment problem effect: situational problems judgment should be more distracting from self-awareness when they are focused on others rather than on self

question2a.value: Interaction effect: Recalling a failure should help avoid problems of situational judgment when they are likely to activate self-awareness and promote the choice of situational judgment problems that distract from self-awareness.

question3a.value: Participants' reactions will be verified to ensure that they have made a clear mention of what has been asked of them.

question5a.value: Self-awareness is the result of a focus on the self. It involves a comparison between the self and standards (Duval and Wicklund, 1972). The perception of the discrepancy between the self and standards is often negative, resulting in negative affects. Failure has a negative impact on our self-image because it leads to a focus on the self and thus an activation of self-awareness. In the case of disappointment, the image of others will be impacted. Disappointment does not, therefore, lead to a focus on the self and does not activate self-awareness. According to the cybernetic theory of self-awareness (Carver and Scheier, 1981) when the reduction of the discrepancy is perceived as impossible, the individual will disengaged physically or mentally from the behavior that causes the focus on the self. Thus, the individual will adopt a behavior that will allow him to avoid a focus on the self and hence, to escape self-awareness. Duval and Wicklund (1972) demonstrated that failure combined with a strong self-focus led to an avoidance of self-awareness. The aim of this study is to demonstrate that individuals are more likely to avoid self-awareness stimuli when they are in a failure rather than a disappointment condition.

question1c.value:
Number of chosen self-focusing judgment problems
Number of chosen other-focused judgment problems

question2c.value: ANOVA repeated measures for within-between interaction will be conducted with 2 recall (failure vs disappointment) x 2 situational judgment problem (self vs others). Main and interaction effects will be considered significant when p < .05.

question3c.value:
IV: memory content (experimental condition), situational judgment problem
DV: self-awareness avoidance (number of chosen self-focusing judgment problems vs number of chosen other-focused others judgment problem)

According to the cybernetic theory of self-awareness (Carver and Scheier, 1981) when the reduction of the discrepancy is perceived as impossible, the individual will disengaged physically or mentally from the behavior that causes the focus on the self. Thus, the individual will adopt a behavior that will allow him to avoid a focus on the self and hence, to escape self-awareness. Duval and Wicklund (1972) demonstrated that failure combined with a strong self-focus led to an avoidance of self-awareness. The aim of this study is to demonstrate that individuals are more likely to avoid self-awareness stimuli when they are in a failure rather than a disappointment condition.

Memory recall (failure vs disappointment): between-participant

Situational judgment problem (self-focusing vs others-focused): within participant
These variables are orthogonal.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants

XXX undergraduate students at the University of Poitiers received partial course credit for participation in what was presented as a memory and judgment study. Participants were randomly assigned to one of the two boxes of a plan 2 (memory recall: failure, disappointment) x 2 (situational judgment problem: self vs other). The first variable is between-subject and the second is within-subject.

Materials, procedure and measures

Memory recall and performance at situational judgment problem
The experience included two tasks. The first task was a recall of memory (failure or disappointment). In the experimental condition, participants had to recall a failure in an area important to them where they had a lower performance compared to another person. They also had to detail the traits that characterized them, and which may have contributed to their failure. In the control condition, participants were asked to recall a disappointment where someone close to them had behaved below their expectations. They also had to detail the traits that characterized the person and that may have contributed to the disappointing behavior.
The second task was a computer-based situational problem judgment task and was designed with PsychoPy.

After reading the information form and completing the consent forms, participants received a document. This document contained three sheets:
•	A sheet with questions about socio-demographic data
•	A sheet with the instruction of the first task and below a box to write the memory
•	A sheet with the presentation of the second task and an example of a situational judgment problem.
On the first task, participants had fifteen minutes to write a memory. After completing the first task, participants had to open the door for the experimenter to explain the second task. Then participants had to read the third sheet and they had to click "OK" to start the computer-based task. The explanations and instructions were written on the screen.
On the first task, participants had fifteen minutes to write a memory. After completing the first task, participants had to open the door for the experimenter to explain the second task. Then participants had to read the third sheet and they had to click "OK" to start the computer-based task. The explanations and instructions were written on the screen.
The second task was presented as part of data collection for standardizing the test. Participants were asked to choose between two types of situational judgment problems: type 1 (by pressing the “1” key) and type 2 (by pressing the “2” key). Problems type 1 and 2 did not differentiate between them and served to distract participants from identifying the protagonist either by "you" or by a first name in the situational judgment problem statement.
After choosing the type of problem, they read a problem of situational judgment. The protagonist was identified either with the term "you" or with a first name. Then participants could choose to either respond to the problem (by pressing the “A” key), decline the problem and move on to the next (by pressing the “P” key), or terminate the experiment (by pressing the “G” key ). For each situational judgment problem, they were asked to indicate the most effective behavior and then the least effective behavior. To address situational judgment problem, for each of the two responses (most efficient and least efficient behavior) they had to choose among four statements and press the key “1”, “2”, “3” or “4”. Participants could terminate the computer-based task whenever they wanted.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Number of chosen self-focusing judgment problems
Number of chosen other-focused judgment problems

ANOVA repeated measures for within-between interaction will be conducted with 2 recall (failure vs disappointment) x 2 situational judgment problem (self vs others). Main and interaction effects will be considered significant when p < .05.

IV: memory content (experimental condition), situational judgment problem
DV: self-awareness avoidance (number of chosen self-focusing judgment problems vs number of chosen other-focused others judgment problem)
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants must be 18 years old or older.

Data from participants will be collected in part via paper and pencil questionnaire for the socio-demographic data and the recall of memory, and in part using PsychoPy software for the computer-based task.

We used effect size and correlation between repeated measures from a comparable prior study. We had access to approximately 100 participants, which gave us than .99 power to detect an effect of the same size as in the previous study, if there is one in the population.
Data collection will end when the required number of participants (100) is reached.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Data will be screened for outliers based on a 2.5MAD criterion (Leys et al., 2013).

Participants will be excluded if they did not recall a memory (personal failure or disappointment) during the first task.

q1.value: Adaptation and Performance of Generalist and Specialist Teams. The Moderating and Mediating Role of Metaknowledge and Information Processing Capacity.

q2.value: Conny Herbert Antoni, Benedikt Graf, Lukas Reuter, Jan Ole Berndt, Ingo J. Timm, Thomas Ellwart

q3.value:
The goal of this study is to analyze the adaptation behavior of generalist and specialist teams with different knowledge about other team members’ tasks and roles (metaknowledge) and the underlying mechanisms that influence team performance and error in a monitoring and control task. 
During a laboratory experiment, one out of three team members drops out, and the remaining two team members have to adapt and to reorganize team tasks in order to perform effectively. We manipulate (1) team task differentiation (specialist vs. generalist teams) and the knowledge about other team members’ tasks and roles (metaknowledge vs. no metaknowledge). 
The experimental sessions last about 60 minutes in total. In the experiment a computer-based simulation task based on firefighting scenarios is used with different levels of complexity and task difficulty. The amount of knowledge rules the participants have to follow in order to fulfill the task defines task complexity. Task difficulty is increased by the amount of fire outbreaks at different locations (low, medium, high fire intensity). The experiment starts with an introduction phase, a learning phase with three simulation task runs with low, medium, and high difficulty at complexity level 1, followed by a practice phase with low and medium difficulty (three minutes each) at complexity level 2, and a disruption phase with a medium difficulty simulation task run lasting six minutes also at complexity level 2.
We expect specialist teams with metaknowledge to be more efficient in managing the drop out of a team member, and therefore, perform better than generalist teams with or without, and specialist teams with no metaknowledge, as specialist teams with metaknowledge have more information processing capacity than the other team types. Their information processing capacity should be higher compared to teams without metaknowledge as the latter have to inform themselves first about the tasks of the missing team member in order to be able to reorganize their team tasks. Specialist teams with metaknowledge should also have higher information processing capacity than generalist teams with metaknowledge as the latter have less differentiated tasks which makes the reorganizing of team tasks more complex.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1:
Metaknowledge moderates the effect of team task differentiation on team adaptation, performance, and error such that specialist teams with metaknowledge a) adapt faster, b) show overall higher performance, and c) lower errors after the drop out of a team member than generalist teams with metaknowledge. 

Hypothesis 2:
Metaknowledge moderates the effect of team task differentiation on information processing capacity such that specialist teams with metaknowledge have a higher information processing capacity after the drop out of a team member than generalist teams with metaknowledge. 

Hypothesis 3:
Information processing capacity mediates the interactive effect of team task differentiation and metaknowledge on a) team adaptation, b) performance, and c) error.

question.value: The experiment will follow a 2 (task differentiation: generalists vs. specialists) x 2 (metaknowledge vs. no metaknowledge) design (2 factors with 2 levels each). The measured variables overall team performance and objective team adaptation will be assessed on team level. Error, Information processing capacity, and subjective team adaptation are assed on the individual level and then aggregated on team level.

q9.value: The participants register via the experimental subjects portal of the University of Trier. The time slots are randomly allocated to the different conditions. The participants register for these time slots without knowing their allocation.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants will be students from a German university who take part in the experiment for course credit or reimbursement (1.5 credits or 15 €). We calculated the sample size to be N = 80 teams (20 teams per condition), each team consisting of 3 participants leading to a total of 240 participants. Only complete teams can perform the experiment. If an active participant drops out of the experiment or disrupts the experiment, the data of the team is excluded from analysis.

q13.value:
Our target sample size is 240 participants in 80 teams (3 participants in each team). We will attempt to recruit up to 270 participants, assuming some participant dropping out of the experiment or disrupting the experiment.
Level 1: 240
Level 2. 80

q14.value: f = .25 (medium), sig. level = .01, power = .8 resulting in n ~ 20 teams per condition (2x2 design) leading to 240 participants in 80 teams.

question.value:
Generalist vs. Specialist teams. Each participant receives a set of knowledge rules that define their tasks within the teams. Knowledge rules are made up of combinations of differently colored trucks with different truck numbers (truck type), lakes, and houses (e.g., a red truck can fill up water on a yellow lake and extinguish red houses). Experimental groups are manipulated by task distribution within the team. Individuals in generalist teams are assigned one truck per truck type, but allowed to use only certain truck numbers, leading to a generalist task where every individual in a team can extinguish fire on every house type. Individuals in specialist teams were assigned all trucks of specific truck types i.e. all truck numbers of a certain type/color, leading to task distribution where only one individual of a team can extinguish fire on a specific house type.  

Meta-Knowledge. Teams are either provided with information about their team members’ tasks or they only received information about their own tasks. Metaknowledge is displayed on the left user-interface in addition to the role description of the individual presented on the right interface. 

Adaptation. The number of team members changes from 3 to 2 after a dropout.

Information processing capacity (IPC). We used eye tracking for an objective measure of IPC. The simulation map and the displayed rules were set as areas of interest (AOI). Having a high fixation duration on the rules was interpreted as a low information capacity. Eye movement was measured with the VT3 mini eye tracker, utilizing Mangold Vision Software. For team level analyses objective IPC is aggregated on team level. Before aggregating IPC ICC 1 and 2 values are checked.

Team Performance. Team performance was measured as (1) the percentage of houses that remained unburned and (2) the percentage of extinguished fires at the end of each task run. 

Team Error. Simulation log files were used to generate error indicators at the end of each task run. Three different error types were identified: (1) truck use error (e.g., using another participant’s truck), (2) fire extinguishing error (attempting to use wrong colored truck for extinguishing a burning house of a different color), and (3) fueling error (attempting to refuel on an incorrect lake). The overall error score was calculated as the mean of percentage of erroneous actions concerning these three actions. For team level analyses overall error scores are aggregated on team level. Before aggregating error ICC 1 and 2 values are checked.

Team adaptation. Subjective team adaptation was measured with a scale that was adapted and taken from Stoverink et al. (2018) concept of perceived resilience, which suggests that resilient teams, when facing a setback, possess not only the flexibility to adapt, but also the grit to persist and persevere through adversity. The scale included 8 items, e.g. 'we can recover quickly as a team' or 'we can return to our pre-adversity level of performance' (1 = disagree, 6 = strongly agree). For team level analyses team adaptation ratings are aggregated on team level. Before aggregating subjective adaptation ratings, awg and ICC 1 and 2 values are checked.
Objective team adaptation was rated by 2 independent ratings with an adjusted adaptation scale from Georganta (2018). 16 items were subdivided into 4 subscales (situational assessment, plan formulation, plan execution, team learning), e.g. 'The team registers all changes that have occurred carefully' or 'The team develops various action plans' (1 = disagree, 5 = strongly agree).

Manipulation check. 

Meta-Knowledge measures if the manipulation of the Meta-Knowledge was successful, e.g. 'Do you know which vehicles the person is driving at Station 1?' (1 = I know, namely ..., 2 = I don't know).

Control variables.

IPC and performance (percentages of (1) unburned house and (2) extinguished fires) and overall error of the remaining dyad in the last task run of the practice phase (complexity level two, medium task difficulty) are used as control variables for the respective mediating or dependent variables.

Subjective team adaptation is measured as the mean of the respective eight scale items.

Objective team adaptation is measured as the mean of the four subscales. 16 items were subdivided into 4 subscales (situational assessment, plan formulation, plan execution, team learning). The four different aspects of team adaptation are measured as the mean of the respective four items based on the item means of the two raters. 

The overall error score was calculated as the mean percentage of erroneous actions in a task run concerning 1) truck use error (e.g., using another participant’s truck), (2) fire extinguishing error (attempting to use wrong colored truck for extinguishing a burning house of a different color), and (3) fueling error (attempting to refuel on an incorrect lake).

For team level analyses objective IPC and overall error are aggregated on team level by using the mean of the values all team members.

We will test our hypotheses using the regression based PROCESS Macro and more precisely Model 8 for conditional process analysis by Hayes (2018). We will first regress a) team adaptation, b) performance, and c) error (as the dependent variable Y) in separate analyses on the dummy-coded variables task differentiation (as the independent variable X) and metaknowledge (as the moderating variable W) and information processing capacity (as the mediating variable Mi). We will do separate analyses for objective information processing, objective and subjective team adaptation and performance. Information processing capacity, team performance and error in the respective prior simulation tasks with the same task complexity and difficulty are used as covariates.

1_Model2 Hayes model8 research model

attributes.title: Social Feedback Processing Deficits in Individuals with Depression

q1.value: Neural Substrates of Expectancy Violation associated with Social Feedback in Individuals with or without Depression Tendency

q3.value: Depression is associated with social dysfunction, which could be at least explained by impaired social feedback processing in individuals with depression. However, previous studies have used feedback that is rather predictable or have confounded the effect with expectancy violation, i.e., the feedback violated prior predictions. Here, we used the Social Judgment Task that enables to separate expected or unexpected social feedback to explore whether the experience of unexpected social feedback or expectancy violation (and its neural underpinnings), is abnormal in depression.

q4.value: We hypothesize that expectancy violation and anhedonia (loss of interest) play an important role during the altered experience of social feedback in individuals with depression. The hypothesized dysfunction is thought to be mediated by dACC and striatum. The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), and temporoparietal junction (TPJ), two regions previously shown to support mentalising about others, were preferentially recruited when participants perceived individuals violating social expectations (Cloutier et al., 2011). Therefore, mPFC and TPJ are also our regions of interest.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have a cross-sectional fMRI design with group (individuals with high or low depressive mood ) as between-subjects factor.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: So far, the demographic data of 47 participants have been accessed and descriptive statistics for that sample were calculated on December 31, 2019. Concerning the fMRI data, so far I only accessed structural images in order to screen out major movement or other artifacts. Neither did I access functional fMRI images nor conduct any preprocessing, first- or second-level analyses.

question.value:
In a mental health screening of Shenzhen University, the Beck Depression Inventory Second Edition (BDI-II, Beck et al., 1996) and the Trait form of Spielberger's State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T, Spielberger et al., 1983) were administered to all the freshman students (approximately 6000 students). This study included individuals from this sample with subthreshold depression (SD) indexed by BDI-II scores ＞ 13. Note: according to the norms of BDI-II (Zung et al., 1965), a BDI-II score ＞ 13/19/28 indicates mild, moderate, and severe depression.
Exclusion criteria included: (1) any lifetime Axis I disorders other than depression according to Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV-TR Axis I Disorders, Research Version, Non-Patient Edition (SCID-I/NP; First et al., 2002); (2) high level of anxiety, i.e., students with STAI-T scores ranked above 75% of the distribution (He et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2018); (3) seizure disorder; (4) history of head injury with possible neurological sequelae; (5) self-reported prior use of any psychoactive drugs especially medication for depression; (6) current alcohol drug dependence.
Age and gender matched healthy controls (HCs) were recruited from the same sample source as individuals with SD. These participants had scores of depressive severity ＜13 (measured by BDI-II) and satisfied the same exclusion criteria as individuals with SD; furthermore, the HCs were screened with SCID-I/NP to guarantee without depression. Among the students who met the above criteria, 50 individuals (24 individuals with SD and 26 HCs) participated in the current study. Written informed consent was obtained prior to the experiment. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Shenzhen University. 
Prior to entering the fMRI scanner, participants were required to complete four questionnaires: the Self-Rating Depression Scale (SDS), BDI-II, STAI-T and the Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ).
Both the SDS (Zung et al., 1965) and BDI-II (Beck et al., 1996) are widely used questionnaires to assess depressive symptoms. The score of depressive severity measured by the SDS ranges from 0.25 to 1.0, with higher scores corresponding to higher depressive severity. The BDI-II scores from 0 to 63, with high scores indicating a high level of depressive tendency.
The Trait form of Spielberger's State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T; Spielberger et al., 1983) scores from 20 to 80, with high scores corresponding to high levels of anxiety.
The Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ; Torrubia et al., 2001) contains 48 items with a yes/no response format related to specific cues and situations. It includes two subscales: Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward. Higher scores indicate higher levels of sensitivity.

q13.value: Of all 50 participants, three participants failed to complete the experiment due to technical problems or personal discomfort, so the data from 47 individuals were included for data analysis.

q14.value: This sample size (50) comes from previous studies using the same task (Somerville et al., 2010). To confirm this sample size we also considered the number of individuals fulfilling the inclusion criteria, as well as time and funding constraints.

q15.value: Data collection has already been finished at one site, Shenzhen, China. Therefore, we do not include any new participants later than on December 31, 2019, so that data analysis and manuscript writing can be finished until March 31, 2020.

question.value:
Between-subjects variables: individuals with or without depression tendency.
Within-subjects variables (description of task): participants performed the Social Judgment Task (see the figure below). The trial began with a 2-s cue period. An ID photo was presented and participants were required to provide a binary prediction of whether the person on the picture would like or dislike them and make a dichotomous (yes/no) response via two buttons. The cue was then followed by a delay period for a various duration ranging from 1.5 s to 2.5 s while participant’s response was shown on the left side of the photo. Finally, participants received the “actual” feedback (yes/no; 2 to 3 s) from the person on the right side of the photo. Unbeknownst to participants, feedback in the whole task was generated pseudo-randomly by computer with an equal distribution of ‘Yes’ and ‘No’ feedbacks.

Demographic Measures:
•	age
•	gender
•	handedness
Questionnaire Measures:
•	Both the SDS (Zung et al., 1965) and BDI-II (Beck et al., 1996) are widely used questionnaires to assess depressive symptoms. The score of depressive severity measured by the SDS ranges from 0.25 to 1.0, with higher scores corresponding to higher depressive severity. The BDI-II scores from 0 to 63, with high scores indicating a high level of depressive tendency.
•	The Trait form of Spielberger's State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T; Spielberger et al., 1983) scores from 20 to 80, with high scores corresponding to high levels of anxiety.
•	The Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ; Torrubia et al., 2001) contains 48 items with a yes/no response format related to specific cues and situations. It includes two subscales: Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward. Higher scores indicate higher levels of sensitivity.

Behavioral performance related to the Social Judgment Task:
•	reaction time in which participants made ‘Yes’ or 'No' choice
•	the number of trials in which participants made ‘Yes’ or 'No' choice
•	Immediately after the scanning, participants completed a brief questionnaire. The first item required participants to estimate the percentage of positive feedback they received during the experiment. The second item required them to report levels of surprise and satisfaction on a 9-point scale (a high score indicated a high level of surprise or satisfaction) to the following contexts: (1) “I think the pictured individuals like me, and they actually like me”; (2) “I think the pictured individuals like me, but they actually dislike me”; (3) “I think the pictured individuals dislike me, but they actually like me”; (4) “I think the pictured individuals dislike me, and they actually dislike me”.

Neuroimaging measures:
•	whole-brain analyses
•	regions of interest (mPFC, ACC, striatum, TPJ) analyses
•	brain-characteristic correlations

Indices related to the Social Judgment Task:
•	Expectation of social acceptance: Participants make 'Yes' prediction in the cue period
•	Expectation of social rejection: Participants make 'No' prediction in the cue period
•	Expected social acceptance: the participant predicts 'Yes' and the pictured individual says 'Yes'
•	Expected social rejection: the participant predicts 'Yes', but the pictured individual says 'No'
•      Unexpected social acceptance: the participant predicts 'No', but the pictured individual says 'Yes'
•      Unexpected social rejection: the participant predicts 'No' and the pictured individual says 'No'

In addition, we will calculate the positive prediction rate to measure the behavioural tendency of predicting that the participant would be socially accepted by peers, by dividing the number of trials in which participants made ‘Yes’ choice by the total number of responded trials.

Behavioural data:
•	Two-way repeated-measures ANOVA will be performed on reaction time (RT) in the cue stage, with choice (Yes or No) as the within-subject factors and group (SD or HC) as the between-subject factor. 
•	For demographic variables, questionnaire variables, and positive prediction rate, independent samples t-test (two-tailed) will be performed between groups.

Neuroimaging data:
•	Image preprocessing will be performed using SPM8. It will include:
  -	Slice timing 
  -	Realignment (Artifact detection will be conducted using the Artifact Detection Tools (ART) toolbox (https://www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect))
  -	Coregistration using the T1-weighted 3D images
  -	Segmentation of the structural image
  -	Spatial normalization to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI)-space
  -	Spatial smoothing with an isotropic Gaussian kernel with an 6 mm full width at half maximum (FWHM). We will choose this parameter for spatial smooth as it was double the voxel size (3 mm) and would retain resolution for identifying changes in the relatively small brain regions we are interested in (see Pizzagalli et al., 2009; Ubl et al., 2015)
•	We will conduct first- and second-level analyses for our event-related fMRI design using the general linear model (GLM) approach
  -     In the first-level analysis for each participant, regressors including 2 delay conditions (expectation after “Yes” and “No”) and 4 feedback conditions (‘Yes’－‘Yes’, ‘Yes’－‘No’, ‘No’－‘Yes’, ‘No’－‘No’) will be modeled (a total of 6 factors). To account for variance caused by head movement, six realignment motion parameters (3 translations/rotations) and outlier scans identified by the ART toolbox will be included as nuisance regressors in the model. Each normalized image will be high-pass filtered using a cutoff time constant of 128 s. Contrast images will be separately calculated for both delay and feedback stages. Contrasts in delay stage will include 1) expectation after “Yes”, 2) expectation after “No”. Contrasts in the feedback stage will include 1) Yes-Yes, 2) Yes-No, 3) No-Yes, and 4) No-No. The baseline used for the task will be the implicit baseline as calculated by SPM.
   -     These contrast images will be taken to the second-level analysis. First, we will perform one-sample t-tests, in which whole-brain analyses will be computed for all contrasts separately for individuals with SD and HCs to identify whether the paradigm will activate brain regions as established in previous studies (Gunther Moor et al., 2010; Powers et al., 2013; Somerville et al., 2006; Somerville et al., 2010). To detect group differences, two-sample t-tests will be also conducted at the whole-brain level. These tests will be set to a threshold of family-wise error (FWE)- or false discovery rate (FDR)- corrected p < 0.05. 
-     From our a priori defined ROIs, ACC and striatum will be anatomically derived from the automated anatomical labelling in the Wake Forest University Pick Atlas (WFUPick Atlas v2.5; http://fmri.wfubmc.edu/software/PickAtlas). The TPJ (left: −53, −59, 20; right: 56, −56, 18) spherical ROI of 6 mm will be defined based on MNI coordinates taken from a recent meta-analysis of Theory of Mind studies (Schurz et al., 2014). The MPFC region from Powers et al. (2013; MNI coordinates 6, 54, 21; 6 mm sphere) and Schurz et al (2014; MNI coordinates −1, 56, 24; 6 mm sphere) will be combined into the ROI of MPFC. Peak activations will be extracted from ROIs that reached significance threshold of p < 0.012 with FWE or FDR correction (Bonferroni adjusted accounting for four ROIs) using the MarsBaR function (Matthew et al., 2002). Maximum peak activations will be submitted to statistical analysis and plotted to further characterize the activations for all trial types in these brain regions.

Brain-characteristic correlations:
•	For each participant, beta weights will be extracted from ROIs that reached significance during second-level analyses for both anticipation and consumption stages. The extracted beta weights represent the magnitude of peak activation for each significant ROI, which will be used to test for the degree of association between characteristic measures and anticipation- and consumption-related brain activation. To assess brain-characteristic correlations, we will calculate group-wise Pearson’s partial correlation coefficients separately for individuals with SD and HCs to allow for statistical non-independence (p < 0.05; two-tailed; Poldrack and Mumford, 2009; Ubl et al., 2015). Depression severity measured by the SDS will be controlled. The Fisher r-to-z transformation (Zar, 1996) will be applied to assess the significance of the difference between two correlation coefficients.

q21.value:
Behavioural data:
We will use the standard p ＜ .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the independent samples t-test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

Neuroimaging data:
We will use a significance level of p ＜ .05, family-wise error corrected (FWE) or false discovery rate (FDR) for multiple comparisons, for ROI-analyses as well as for exploratory whole-brain analyses.

To assess brain-characteristic correlations, we will calculate group-wise Pearson’s partial correlation coefficients separately for individuals with SD and HCs to allow for statistical non-independence (p ＜ 0.05; two-tailed; Poldrack and Mumford, 2009; Ubl et al., 2015).

q22.value:
Participants who failed to complete the experiment (due to technical problems or personal discomfort) will not be included in data analysis.

Before pre-processing the fMRI data, the first five volumes will be discarded because of signal equilibration and participants’ adaptation to scanning noise.

When using ART toolbox to detect artifacts, global mean intensity ( ＞ 2 standard deviations from mean image intensity for the entire scan) and motion ( ＞ 2 mm) outliers will be identified and entered as a regressor of no interest in the first-level general linear model (GLM) (Stoodley et al., 2012).

Neuroimaging data related to oo-response trials, i.e., participants did not respond within the 2-s cue period will be deleted.

q23.value: Participants will be excluded for further analysis if functional or structural MRI-data are incomplete due to early termination of the SJ task or technical issues.

q24.value: We plan to conduct this exploratory analysis: A whole-brain analysis for each group (individuals with SD, HC) for each contrast (as stated in "Statistical models"), respectively.

registration_responses.q1: Neural Substrates of Expectancy Violation associated with Social Feedback in Individuals with or without Depression Tendency
registration_responses.q3: Depression is associated with social dysfunction, which could be at least explained by impaired social feedback processing in individuals with depression. However, previous studies have used feedback that is rather predictable or have confounded the effect with expectancy violation, i.e., the feedback violated prior predictions. Here, we used the Social Judgment Task that enables to separate expected or unexpected social feedback to explore whether the experience of unexpected social feedback or expectancy violation (and its neural underpinnings), is abnormal in depression.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that expectancy violation and anhedonia (loss of interest) play an important role during the altered experience of social feedback in individuals with depression. The hypothesized dysfunction is thought to be mediated by dACC and striatum. The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), and temporoparietal junction (TPJ), two regions previously shown to support mentalising about others, were preferentially recruited when participants perceived individuals violating social expectations (Cloutier et al., 2011). Therefore, mPFC and TPJ are also our regions of interest.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

Neither did I access functional fMRI images nor conduct any preprocessing, first- or second-level analyses.

registration_responses.q14: This sample size (50) comes from previous studies using the same task (Somerville et al., 2010). To confirm this sample size we also considered the number of individuals fulfilling the inclusion criteria, as well as time and funding constraints.

registration_responses.q8.question: We have a cross-sectional fMRI design with group (individuals with high or low depressive mood ) as between-subjects factor.
registration_responses.q12.question:
In a mental health screening of Shenzhen University, the Beck Depression Inventory Second Edition (BDI-II, Beck et al., 1996) and the Trait form of Spielberger's State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T, Spielberger et al., 1983) were administered to all the freshman students (approximately 6000 students). This study included individuals from this sample with subthreshold depression (SD) indexed by BDI-II scores ＞ 13. Note: according to the norms of BDI-II (Zung et al., 1965), a BDI-II score ＞ 13/19/28 indicates mild, moderate, and severe depression.
Exclusion criteria included: (1) any lifetime Axis I disorders other than depression according to Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV-TR Axis I Disorders, Research Version, Non-Patient Edition (SCID-I/NP; First et al., 2002); (2) high level of anxiety, i.e., students with STAI-T scores ranked above 75% of the distribution (He et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2018); (3) seizure disorder; (4) history of head injury with possible neurological sequelae; (5) self-reported prior use of any psychoactive drugs especially medication for depression; (6) current alcohol drug dependence.
Age and gender matched healthy controls (HCs) were recruited from the same sample source as individuals with SD. These participants had scores of depressive severity ＜13 (measured by BDI-II) and satisfied the same exclusion criteria as individuals with SD; furthermore, the HCs were screened with SCID-I/NP to guarantee without depression. Among the students who met the above criteria, 50 individuals (24 individuals with SD and 26 HCs) participated in the current study. Written informed consent was obtained prior to the experiment. The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Shenzhen University. 
Prior to entering the fMRI scanner, participants were required to complete four questionnaires: the Self-Rating Depression Scale (SDS), BDI-II, STAI-T and the Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ).
Both the SDS (Zung et al., 1965) and BDI-II (Beck et al., 1996) are widely used questionnaires to assess depressive symptoms. The score of depressive severity measured by the SDS ranges from 0.25 to 1.0, with higher scores corresponding to higher depressive severity. The BDI-II scores from 0 to 63, with high scores indicating a high level of depressive tendency.
The Trait form of Spielberger's State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T; Spielberger et al., 1983) scores from 20 to 80, with high scores corresponding to high levels of anxiety.
The Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ; Torrubia et al., 2001) contains 48 items with a yes/no response format related to specific cues and situations. It includes two subscales: Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward. Higher scores indicate higher levels of sensitivity.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Between-subjects variables: individuals with or without depression tendency.
Within-subjects variables (description of task): participants performed the Social Judgment Task (see the figure below). The trial began with a 2-s cue period. An ID photo was presented and participants were required to provide a binary prediction of whether the person on the picture would like or dislike them and make a dichotomous (yes/no) response via two buttons. The cue was then followed by a delay period for a various duration ranging from 1.5 s to 2.5 s while participant’s response was shown on the left side of the photo. Finally, participants received the “actual” feedback (yes/no; 2 to 3 s) from the person on the right side of the photo. Unbeknownst to participants, feedback in the whole task was generated pseudo-randomly by computer with an equal distribution of ‘Yes’ and ‘No’ feedbacks.

The MPFC region from Powers et al. (2013; MNI coordinates 6, 54, 21; 6 mm sphere) and Schurz et al (2014; MNI coordinates −1, 56, 24; 6 mm sphere) will be combined into the ROI of MPFC. Peak activations will be extracted from ROIs that reached significance threshold of p < 0.012 with FWE or FDR correction (Bonferroni adjusted accounting for four ROIs) using the MarsBaR function (Matthew et al., 2002). Maximum peak activations will be submitted to statistical analysis and plotted to further characterize the activations for all trial types in these brain regions.

Brain-characteristic correlations:
•	For each participant, beta weights will be extracted from ROIs that reached significance during second-level analyses for both anticipation and consumption stages. The extracted beta weights represent the magnitude of peak activation for each significant ROI, which will be used to test for the degree of association between characteristic measures and anticipation- and consumption-related brain activation. To assess brain-characteristic correlations, we will calculate group-wise Pearson’s partial correlation coefficients separately for individuals with SD and HCs to allow for statistical non-independence (p < 0.05; two-tailed; Poldrack and Mumford, 2009; Ubl et al., 2015). Depression severity measured by the SDS will be controlled. The Fisher r-to-z transformation (Zar, 1996) will be applied to assess the significance of the difference between two correlation coefficients.

name.value: STORM: Study of Open Research Methods in Psychology students

other.value:
We will finish data collection when we have collected 3750 responses including at least 10 responses from each university in the UK, or by June 30th 2020, whichever is earlier. 

Analysis: 
•	We may also complete a 2-way ANOVA exploring the interaction between University status and year group. If there are sufficient responses for UKRN and non-UKRN groups in each year group, we will run a 2-way ANOVA instead of these two 1-way ANOVAs. 

•	If for Analysis 3, the distribution is skewed, we will treat the ordinal scores as a categorical variable and will complete a chi-squared of 8 (open research principles) x 5 (response categories).

•	A major part of this project/paper will be to provide descriptive statistics, including figures, showing how the sample performs on each item and scale. To our knowledge, these statistics will provide the first bench marks of Open Research knowledge, perceptions, awareness and experience in Psychology students in the UK.

sample.value:
The goal of this study is to recruit a representative sample of university students in the UK. Hence, we aim to recruit approximately 3750 undergraduate psychology students across universities in the UK. This equates to a sample of 30 students from each of the 125 UK universities that offer an Undergraduate Psychology degree. 

Note: As determined using GPower for the largest proposed analysis (one-way ANOVA with 4 groups), to achieve power of 80% with an alpha of 0.05 and a small effect size of 0.10, 1200 participants are required.

analyses.value:
1. Does the DV differ by academic year group?

For ordinal DV’s, Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) with year group (Year 1, Year 2, placement year, final year) as an Independent variable and the outcome measure as a Dependent Variable. For this and all other year group analysis, the responses of part time students will be converted such that the students are allocated to the year group that they would be in, if they were completing a course full-time. 

For the categorical DVs we will use chi-squared to analyse the data. The Independent variables will be categorical response (0, 1) and academic year group (Year 1, Year 2, placement year, final year). 

2. Does the DV differ by University status (member of UKRN, not member of UKRN)?

For ordinal DVs, t-tests will be completed with university status (member of UKRN, not member of UKRN) as an Independent variable and the outcome measure as a Dependent Variable. For categorical DV’s we will use chi-squared to analyse the data. The Independent variables will be categorical response (0,1) and university status group (member of UKRN, not member of UKRN). 

3. Does performance on the primary DV’s differ for different Open Science principles?

For each DV, we will investigate differences in responses across different Open Research principles (Open data; Open materials/code; Open access journals; Study preregistration; Print archiving/Preprints; Open educational materials; Power analysis; Replication Studies). We will use one-way ANOVA with score as the Dependent variable and Open Research principle as an Independent variable. 

For categorical DV’s, we will use Chi-squared to investigate differences in responses across the different principles, i.e., a chi-squared of 8 (open research principles) x 2 (response categories). 

4.Does performance on the different ordinal DV’s differ? 

For the primary DV’s only, we will convert the DV’s described in section 3 into z-scores and use repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) to compare performance across scales, i.e., the dependent variable will be z-score and the Independent variable will be scale (knowledge, perception, awareness, experience)

For all analyses we will correct for multiple comparisons. 
For ANOVAs and t-tests we will treat ordinal variables as continuous.

outliers.value:
1. Completion Rules: We have designed this questionnaire so that participants cannot progress without answering (where appropriate) all items. For participants who fail to complete the questionnaire, i.e., stop mid-way through, their responses will only be included for scales (DV’s) where they have provided an answer for every item on the scale. For comparisons across scales, participants who have missing data for any one scale will be excluded from this analysis.  

2. University Response Rates: If there are fewer than 10 responses from a given university, that are eligible for inclusion, these participants will be excluded from all analyses. 

3. Minimum time cap: Based on piloting, we propose that the shortest amount of time that can be taken to meaningfully complete this survey is 4 minutes. Anyone with a full set of responses and a completion time that is shorter than 4 minutes, will be excluded from all analyses. 

4. Open Answer Questions: For items where participants have to write an answer, instead of selecting from a set of tick boxes, participants will be excluded from any analysis based on this item, if their response is inappropriate or incomprehensible.

dependent.value:
Primary DV’s:
Perceptions of Open Research: 16 item scale with scores for each item awarded as follows: strongly disagree (-2), disagree (-1), have no opinion (0), agree (1) or strongly agree (2). Items will be reverse coded where required. The maximum score is 32 indicating Open Research principles are perceived as important/good and a minimum score of -32 indicating that Open Science principles are perceived as unimportant/bad. 

Awareness of Open Research: 8 Item (Yes or No) scale with a maximum score of 8 indicating high levels of awareness and a minimum score of 0 indicating low awareness. 

Experience of Open Research: 8 item (yes or no) scale with a maximum score of 8 indicating high lots of experience and a minimum score of 0 indicating little experience. 

Knowledge of Open Research: 8 item scale with scores for each item awarded as follows: Strongly Disagree (0), Disagree (1), Have no opinion (2), Agree (3), Strongly Agree (4). Items will be reverse coded where required. The maximum score is 32 indicating good (high) knowledge of Open Research. The minimum score is 0 indicating poor (low) knowledge of Open Research.

Note: For each Primary DV the items presented assess 8 Open Research principles (Open data; Open materials/code; Open access journals; Study preregistration; Print archiving/Preprints; Open educational materials; Power analysis; Replication Studies). 

Secondary DV’s
Awareness of the replication / reproducibility crisis: Categorical response of 1 (aware of it) or 0 (not aware of it or unsure). For this item unsure is coded as 0. 

Knowledge of what replication/reproducibility crisis is: Categorical response of 1 (correct answer/description given) or 0 (incorrect answer/description given). 

Learnt about the replication / reproducibility crisis on university course: Categorical response of 1 (learnt about it) or 0 (didn’t learn about it or unsure). For this item unsure is coded as 0.

Learnt about Open Research/Open Science on university course: Categorical response of 1 (learnt about it) or 0 (didn’t learn about it or unsure). For this item unsure is coded as 0.

Could explain Open Research/Science to another student: Categorical response of 1 (Yes) or 0 (No or Unsure). For this item unsure is coded as 0.

Applicability of open science/reproducibility: Categorical response of 1 (applicable to undergraduate students) or 0 (not applicable to undergraduate students). For this item unsure is coded as 0.

conditions.value: There is no allocation to conditions in this study

hypothesis.value:
The primary aim of this research is to investigate knowledge, perceptions, awareness and experience of Open Research in Undergraduate Psychology students in the UK.

1. For each of each of the Dependent Variables listed below, does the DV differ by academic year group? 

2. For each of each of the Dependent Variables listed below, does the DV differ by University status (member of UKRN, not member of UKRN)?

3. Does performance on each of the primary DV’s differ for different Open Science principles including: Open data; Open materials/code; Open access journals; Study preregistration; Print archiving/Preprints; Open educational materials; Power analysis; Replication Studies?

4. How does student’s performance on the different ordinal DV’s differ?

other.value:
Some exploratory analyses may be conducted, testing if the need threats mediate the relation between conditions and lower expectations of chances in the job market, and feelings of demotivation. We will also test if expectation of chances in the job market mediates the relation between conditions and experienced demotivation.

In the results, we describe p-values equal or below 0.05 to be significant, between 0.05 and 0.10 to be marginally significant, and above 0.10 to be non-significant.

sample.value: We collect data for around 60 participants per cell, 180 participants in total. Data will be collected among British women on the Prolific platform. Due to the exclusion criteria we expect the usable sample to be somewhat smaller.

analyses.value:
For all hypotheses, we will first perform a one-way ANOVA, testing for differences between the three conditions on each dependent variable. Then, two simple contrasts are conducted. Contrast 1 compares confirmations of sexism with the control condition. Contrast 2 compares confirmations of sexism with denials of sexism.

For H1, the above analyses are performed with exclusion as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating higher feelings of exclusion after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating higher feelings of exclusion after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism OR b) not significant, indicating equal feelings of exclusion after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H2, the same analyses are performed with negative feelings as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating more negative feelings after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating more negative feelings after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equally negative feelings after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H3, the same analyses are performed with need threats as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating needs are more threatened after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating the needs to be more threatened after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal need threats after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H4, the same analyses are performed with expectations of success as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating expectations of chances of moving up in the job market to be lower after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating expectations to be lower after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal expectations after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H5, the same analyses are performed with demotivation as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating higher experienced demotivation towards achieving a desirable job position after exposure to confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating higher demotivation after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal demotivation after confirmations and denials of sexism.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from the analyses if:

- They do not indicate they identify as female.
- They do not stay on the page with the manipulation text for longer than 4 seconds (in the denial of sexism and confirmation of sexism conditions).
- They do not complete the full survey.

dependent.value:
Exclusion: "At this moment I feel excluded”, (1 = Not at all, 7 = Completely).

Negative feelings: “At this moment I feel..”, “sad”, “angry”, “hurt”, “happy”, “elated”, “cheerful”, last three items reverse coded (1 = Not at all, 7 = Completely, adapted from Van Beest & Williams, 2006). All items are collapsed into one measure of 'feelings' if reliability allows.

Need threats: Need threat is expressed on 7-point semantic differential scales (Rudert & Greifeneder, 2016). "At this moment I feel..", "rejected–accepted”, (belonging), “devalued–valued”, (self-esteem), “powerless–powerful”, (control) and “invisible–recognized” (meaningful existence)". All are collapsed into one measure of need threats, if reliability allows.

Expectations of success: Participants are asked to think of an organization they would like to work in, and then answer two questions: “Personally, I think that compared to an equally skilled male candidate, my chances of getting promoted to a desirable position within this organization are..” (where 1 = Much lower, 7 = Much higher), and "Personally, I think that compared to an equally skilled male candidate, my chances of moving up in this organization are.." (1 = Much lower, 7 = Much higher). Both items are collapsed into one measure of expectation of success, if reliability allows.

Demotivation is measured with two questions: “How do you feel about trying to acquire a position higher up in this organization?, answer options 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged, and 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.

As a control question, participants indicate which field the organization that they thought of operates in: "When answering these questions about this organisation, an organization in which field did you think of?".

conditions.value:
Participants are assigned to one of three condition: denial of sexism vs. confirmation of sexism vs. a control condition.

In the denial of sexism condition participants read that a previous study among British participants demonstrated that the vast majority of the people think that: a) men and women have equal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is no longer a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to other factors than discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated equally, and e) women are almost never treated in a sexist manner.

In the confirmation of sexism condition, participants read that the vast majority of people think that: a) men and women have unequal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is still a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated unequally, and e) women are often treated in a sexist manner.

In the control condition participants are asked to answer some questions, and are told that they will get to read the results of a previous study afterwards.

hypothesis.value:
In news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality, which confirms the occurrence of sexism. This contradicts modern sexist beliefs that deny the occurrence of sexism. In the current research we compare how women respond to denials of sexism vs. confirmations of sexism. We test whether being confronted with messages that confirm the prevalence of sexism may make women feel excluded, and frustrate their expectations and motivation to achieve higher positions in society.

H1: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings of exclusion are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H2: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings are more negative than in the control condition, and equally or more negative than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H3: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s needs are more threatened than in the control condition, and equally or more threatened than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H4: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s expectations of their chances to move up in the job market are lower than in the control condition, and similar or lower than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H5: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s experiences of demotivation towards acquiring a desirable job position are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.
