attributes.description: This project aims to look at conflicting predictions of cultural and biological kinship theories, and determie their impact on cooperative beahviour.

q1.value: What do kinterms do: a test of cultural and biological predictions on kin-based cooperation

q3.value: Anthropology’s one-hundred and fifty year love-affair with kinship began with the discovery of descriptive and classificatory kin terms (Morgan 1871). From this moment, anthropologists have questioned the implications of different kinship systems and how they interact with the development of human society (Godelier 2012; Murdock 1949). For example: In Hindi the term ‘dīdī’ is used to refer to both an elder sister and the elder daughter of a parent’s sibling (i.e. female cousin). Why is it that for native Hindi speakers this is a natural classification, whereas for an English speaker it seems dissonant? Anthropological theory proposes that patterns of social organisation (such as marriage, descent, and residence) prescribe cultural expectations of behaviour (e.g. being cooperative) towards particular categories of kin. The variation in expected behaviour is operationalised by categorizing kin under the same term. Terms that cover multiple relatives can be one of two types, descriptive or classificatory. The initial definition of classificatory kinterms has been interpreted ambiguously over time: here we use the original definition: grouping collateral and lineal kin under a single kinterm (although it could reasonably be extended to include affinal kin, Dole 1972). Under a cultural understanding of kinship terminologies, a person should expect to have similar relationships with all relatives called dīdī, or to use an English example, a person might expect to have similar relationships to a consanguineal uncle and an affinal uncle. Biological understandings of kinship suggest kin-oriented behaviour is primarily driven by improving one’s genetic fitness through the theory of kin-selection (Hamilton’s rule). This idea predicts that cooperative behaviour will occur when the cost to the co-operator (c) is outweighed by the benefit to the recipient (b), multiplied by their relatedness (r, formulated as: br > c, Hamilton, 1964). The cultural classification of kin has been largely ignored in biological studies of kinship, which has resulted in opposing predictions in biological and cultural theories of kinship. If we assume that both the benefit and cost are constant in some hypothetical situation, we would predict that on average an individual would prefer to cooperate with sister over a cousin, or a consanguineal over an affinal uncle, contrary to the cultural prediction of treating them equally. This dichotomy is what we will explore in this experiment.

q4.value:
Here we propose that the reason these dichotomous predictions exist is because cultural and biological domains of kinship are at opposing ends of the same scale and that their relative importance is contextually constrained. The influence of each domain is the result of a trade-off between what we call social-cost and genetic-cost. Social-cost is when the cost of not behaving appropriately impacts social standing; for example, not attending a relative’s birthday or excluding them from inheritance. Genetic-cost is when there is impact on genetic fitness; for example, having to save a relative from life-threatening situations, but also caring for relative’s offspring or making marital decisions. With significant variation in kinship organisation, parsing the interaction of these two processes can help explain cross-cultural variation in kin-oriented behaviour, but also unveil how our cultural environment interacts with biological predispositions. We test the predictions across two languages, Indian Hindi and America, where Indian Hindi contains a single classificatory term for elder sister and father’s brother’s elder daughter (dīdī), and English contains distinct terms (sister / cousin). This difference in kinship organisation allows us to test the impact of cultural difference, against the human universal response of kin-selection theory.  

We therefore propose two hypotheses: 
1. In high social-cost situations, classificatory relationships will be prioritised over genealogical and there will be a difference in behaviour between Indian and English participants

2. In high genetic-cost situations, genealogical relationship will be prioritised over classificatory and there will be no difference in behaviour between Indian and English participants. 

These are operationalised in to 5 scenarios (available in the draft survey attached to the study design section):

Scenario 1: high social cost and low genetic cost
	Birthday parties
Scenario 2a: low social cost and high genetic cost
	Babysitting
Scenario 2b: low social cost and high genetic cost
	Life of death situation
Scenario 3: low social cost and low genetic cost
	Moving house
Scenario 4: high social cost and high genetic cost
	Inheritance / Wills

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
There is no experimental design in the study. Each participant will respond to a set of scenarios about a fictional family and answer a survey on their demographic background. We hope to observe differences based on cultural and linguistic backgrounds. 

Attached is a draft of what a participant would see in the English version of the experiment. Including the all scenarios individuals will be asked to answer.

q9.value: We will randomize the order in which participants will see scenarios.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Recruitment: 
Participants will be recruited through Mechanical Turk (which has a large subscription of American and Indian workers).

We predict the survey will take five minutes to complete.

Payment: 
All participants will be paid the American living wage for their time: USD$1.30 (Living wage / hour: USD$16.07). There are some concerns that this will impact responses from India, where the value of US dollars is higher, however recent research suggests this is only the case when monetary rewards are USD$10 or higher (Raihani et al. 2013). 

Exclusion: 
Checks will be used to determine if participants were bots or not paying sufficient attention, such as time spent on each page, or the intelligibility of free-text results. Participants will also be assessed on their language fluency prior to starting the test and asked to fill in an attention survey at the end of the task, to ensure they understood and conducted the task appropriately. If participants are deemed to be bots, then they will be excluded, and payment withheld. If participants fail the language fluency test, they will not be allowed to continue and payment withheld. Payment, in this case, is withheld on the grounds that they have falsely claimed to fulfil the requirements of participation. If participants are deemed to not have been paying sufficient attention, then they will be excluded from analysis, but payment will not be withheld if they have spent sufficient time on the task. This is under the assumption that the failure to understand is a design flaw on our part. All exclusions will be documented in the supplementary material and the OSF project page.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants, 100 English speakers from USA and 100 Hindi speakers from India. We will continue to recruit participants until this number is reached. All responses will be validated before payment to ensure incomplete survey's do not reduce our target sample size.

q14.value:
A sample of 200 is restricted by time and cost. 

With a sample size of 200 we will be able to detect an effect size of 0.139 with 0.9 power at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability. This was determined using the R package 'pwr'

However, the results will be analysed using Bayesian methods.

q15.value: We will continue to collect participants until we reach 100 participants from each population. Some of these participants may need to be excluded from the analysis based on our previously stated criteria: if more than 25% of the participants need to be excluded, we will restart the search for more participants, continuing until we reach 100 from each group again (while ensuring we don’t have repeat workers).

question.value: This study is observational, so no variables are manipulated. Participants are asked to make decisions for a fictional character in 5 scenarios, and our predictions are about how different cultural and linguistic backgrounds will change the answer to those questions.

Allocation: The relative amount of time or resources given to a particular individual in each scenario. 

Language: What language is the participants first language. 

Scenario: The ID number of the scenario that the participant has completed. 

Demographic variables: Gender, Age, Language, Education

Living Abroad: How long and where individuals have lived abroad may affect their cultural / linguistic beliefs

Interaction with relatives: We ask the following questions on how often the participants sees / interacts with their relatives
-	How often do you see [X relative]
-	How close do you live to [X relative]
This will be used to test exploratory hypotheses on how an individuals family experience impacted their response.
NOTE: this file is the Power calculations for the Sample size rationale section

Both our hypotheses will be tested in a single multi-level model: 

allocation ~ scenario * language + gender + (1|ID) 

A reminder that our hypotheses are: 

1. In social-cost situations, classificatory relationships will be prioritised over genealogical 

2. In genetic-cost situations, genealogical relationship will be prioritised over classificatory 

In terms of this model, using scenario 1 and Hindi as baseline levels: H1 should see a significant interaction between scenario 1 and 3 and language H2 should see no significant interaction between scenario 2a, 2b, 4 and language That is, when it is a high social-cost situation, we expect to see a difference between the two populations (since social costs are dependent on cultural background), and when it is a high genetic-cost situation, we expect to see no difference (as genetic-costs are equal for all humans). 

We will also use model comparisons tests with and without the language variable to test the importance of language (or cultural background) is in determining the outcome for each of the scenarios. 

Scenarios are presented in the survey mock-up document in the design section.

See attached RScript for simulated results. The simulation excludes a random intercept for individuals, which will be necessary in the observed data to account for the repeated responses of participants across scenarios.

q20.value:
In addition to the model above, we will also run the model with a log transformed response. This is under the assumption that participants will respond on a non-linear scale. 

We will also run models with continuous responses, and binary responses. Where binary responses are determined by a 10% bias towards either relative.

q21.value: We will use BayesFactors to make inferences. BF <3 indicates weak evidence, >3 positive evidence, between 5 and 10 strong evidence, and <10 very strong evidence

q22.value: We will verify that participants completed the survey. We have an awareness test to ensure that participants understood the relationship between all the characters. We will check geo-tags to ensure Indian participants are in India, and American participants are in America. We will have a language check to ensure participants have sufficient fluency in the language. We will exclude incomplete responses and responses which appear to have misunderstood the survey. We will run models with and without participants who appear to have travelled or lived in other countries for significant periods of time.

q24.value: We may also look at the effects of the demographic variables we collect on response, and their interaction with predicted responses.
